direction.raw_text: the slow, solemn tones that announce a death. A dozen men in scarlet cassocks, ROMAN CATHOLIC CARDINALS, bend down to inspect the ring, nodding in affirmation, part of an ancient ritual. A younger man (the CAMERLENGO) in a black cassock takes a silver knife and scratches the ring's seal twice, once horizontally and once vertically, in the sign of the cross. Now the ring is placed on a lead block.    The Camerlengo raises a silver mallet and SMASHES it down, shattering the ring into a thousand tiny pieces. As the Cardinals confirm to their satisfaction that the ring has been destroyed, the HUSHED VOICE of a NEWS REPORTER comes over the image.

He walks, lit by candlelight that throws harsh shadows on strange walls. There are a DOZEN TOURISTS scattered around, and a TOUR GROUP on one side hearing a lecture from a MUSEUM DOCENT. Langdon looks up at the hole in the ceiling through which a bright shaft of light is shining.

Tourists.   Couples. Teenagers.    More tourists. Around every column, there are shadows, and in those shadows -- --- nothing. He looks at his watch.    Five minutes to eight.       And then -- --- a SHRIEK from the other side of the room.      He whirls, sees Vittoria backing away from something.

direction.raw_text: Langdon takes off running, toward and eleventh-century church at the southwest corner of the plaza, covered in scaffolding. At the front door of the church, Langdon hops over the sawhorses blocking the entrance and tries the door.    Locked.    A sign says the place is under construction. At a side door, Olivetti races alongside the church, followed by the others. He reaches a door with a large, heavy ring, and pulls it toward him. But the door won t budge.    He pushes, throws his shoulder into it.    Locked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Olivetti just races onward, looking for another door, followed by Vincenzo.    As they disappear around the back of the church, Langdon steps up to the large ring, gives it an almighty twist -- INT       SANTA MARIA DEL POPOLO            DUSK -- and the heavy door CLUNKS open. The interior of the church is an obstacle course of torn-up flooring, brick pallets, mounds of dirt.    Silt drifts in the dying sunlight that shines through the broken windows and walls. Nothing moves.    Dead silence.    Langdon and Vittoria walk slowly to the middle of the floor, at one end of the chapel. There are eight recesses, four on either side of a central aisle, all covered with large sheets of plastic, to protect them during construction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The plastic RUSTLES ominously.       Anything could be behind any one of them. Vittoria pulls the gun from her waistband and holds it in front of her.    Langdon notices, it makes him uncomfortable.

direction.raw_text: She looks at him --- what are you, nuts? Something rushes at them from the side, she whirls -- --- and nearly blows Olivetti to kingdom come as he and Vincenzo barrel in through the side door. Langdon gestures --- everybody quiet. Olivetti points to the left gestures to Langdon and Vittoria to go to the right. They separate, to either side of the main aisle.

Chartrand's already slumped against a wall, his radio in hand, keying it over and over again, but getting only static.

direction.raw_text: Langdon blinks, his vision becoming seriously impaired. He holds his eyes closed for a moment, opens them, it's not much better. Langdon looks at the glass wall on the far side of the vault. Then at the row of bookcases.    Gets an idea. He goes to the last bookcase, which is about six feet from the glass wall. He hoists himself up on the shelf of the bookcase opposite it, wedges himself in. And pushes with one leg.      The giant bookcase teeters, but just barely. Langdon hoists himself further up, gets both legs up against the bookshelf. Pushes again -- more movement this time. Now he puts everything he has into it, straining like hell.    The bookcase starts to tip, goes just past the point of no return, starts to fall, gloriously headed straight for the glass wall, which it SLAMS into with enormous power and -- --- stops. Leaning against the wall.     Forget cracks, there's not even a scratch. Langdon CURSES under his breath, looks around for another idea. He hears a soft THUD from the other side of the room, sees Chartrand has slumped over, unconscious. But his jacket has fallen open, revealing the sidearm he carries in a shoulder holster.

direction.raw_text: slips the gun out of the holster and hefts it.     Safe bet he's never held one of these before. He staggers over toward the glass wall, raises the gun, and pulls the trigger.    Nothing happens.    Trigger doesn't even move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment of oxygen-poor thinking, he figures out how to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: off the safety.    Tries again. (Pow.) The sound of the shot is barely audible to Langdon.     His brain's going fast. If he was hoping to bring the whole wall down, he failed, but there's a faint HISSING sound coming from the bullethole, and he goes to it and takes a deep breath of air from the outside. He stands back, his brain clearing momentarily. Seized by an idea, he looks up at the wall, at its four corners, and at the tiny web of cracks radiating out from the hole he just made in the center. He raises the gun again and fires off FOUR SHOTS in quick succession.    They're in an odd pattern-- upper left corner, upper right, not quite as high, lower middle-left, and the very lower right corner. Now there are four new holes, each HISSING slightly, and the first hole, in the center. Shaking his head once more to clear it, Langdon steps forward to the glass wall, but instead of barreling against it or throwing a chair, he simply raises one hand, places it flat over the first hole he made, the one in the center of the glass wall --- -- and presses gently. Almost immediately, a SHARP SOUND comes from the hole beneath his hand and a jagged crack leaps out from the first hole, shooting up to connect with the hole in the upper left corner. He presses just a touch harder and a SECOND CRACK starts, shooting down to the lower right.    Then a third, and a fourth, the glass is cracking like ice in springtime, all four extremities connecting with the central hole, and with a huge GROANING SOUND - -

direction.raw_text: Bernini's spectacular Fountain of the Four Rivers in the Piazza Navona. There is a black van parked beside the fountain, and we drift over toward it.    Passing through the passenger window, we go inside to find -- -- Mr. Gray, facing the rear of the van, his jacket off and his shirt open, engaged in battlefield surgery on his injured right shoulder.    Using a long-handled tweezers, he digs into his own flesh, gets a hold of the bullet that pierced him, and tosses it onto the metal floor of the van with a TING. It lands beside a lumpy tarp, and as metal hits metal, the tarp jumps. There's a human being in there.       Mr. Gray speaks to the lump.

But with the new position, his eyes fall on something behind the cardinal -- a plastic tube, six inches across, streaming bubbles into the fountain. He goes back   -- ABOVE THE SURFACE -- takes another breathy and sees the fountain of bubbles rising up to the surface just above the tube.    Air! Langdon takes the tube and draws a couple breaths of his own, then digs his hands back underneath the Cardinal to lift him, but this time -- -- SIX MORE HANDS come in from all sides. dialogue.raw_text: The Vatican used this place for centuries as a hideout, a prison for enemies of the church -- there are passages and catacombs everywhere. dialogue.raw_text: The symbol for the Vatican?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The papacy. (THINKING) They're going to kill him.    Before they blow up the Vatican they're going to kill and brand the pope himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there is no pope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Technically, there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Camerlengo?!    We have to-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY (O.S.) Please place your gun on the floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY   (cont'd) Kick it to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could have been long gone by now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY Some do God's work for love, others for money.    Which do you take me for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY You're not one of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither are you. I was expecting a fanatic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY When they call me -- and they all call me -- it is so important to them that I know what they ask is the Lord's will.    Or Allah's, or Yahweh's.    And I suppose they're right.    Because if He were not vengeful, I would not exist, would I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY (cont'd) Be careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you kill us when you had the chancer
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GRAY Because no one asked me to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rocher reaches the office of the Pope. Two uniformed Swiss Guard are stationed outside. Another Swiss Guardsman steps out of the office, reporting back from within.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Swiss Guards look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocher is truly intimidating when he wants to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods to the other Guards, who raise their swords, allowing access.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Camerlengo says he will grant you an audience.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to see him alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's impossible, sir.    No one-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you forgotten who you work for?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No,   sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vittoria and Langdon barrel down the stone stairs, into the passage, and through the open doorway to Il Passetto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The passetto is narrow and dark, lit only by streaks of moonlight coming through the vertical slits in the walls. But up ahead, there's light.      They race for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo kneels in prayer in front of the fire. He hears a sound behind him and turns as the door to the papal office opens. Rocher enters, closes and locks the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: INT OFFICE OF THE POPE NIGHT
result.heading: INT OFFICE OF THE POPE NIGHT

dialogue.raw_text: Have you come to make me a martyr?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vittoria and Langdon race up a flight of stairs, and the passetto comes out into the open for a hundred yards or so as it leaves the Castel Sant'Angelo. Ahead, they see a rope ladder over the side.        They look down. Directly below them, Mr. Gray is getting into an Alfa Romeo parked discretely at the end of a dead end street, making his escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the car door SLAMS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gray turns the key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Langdon and Vittoria are running toward the Vatican again when the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rips through the still night. They stagger and turn back, in time to see Mr. Gray's car go up in an enormous fireball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Langdon grabs her arm and they take off.        The Passetto descends again, into -- INT       IL PASSETTO       NIGHT -- another underground space.        The outline of a steel gate looms ahead, blocking their way. But as they draw closer, they find the ancient lock hanging open, and the gate swings freely.    This tunnel has been used, and recently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Men of God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: they plow onward, and now there is a low ROARING sound from above them.    Langdon pauses, looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They keep on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're under St. Peter's Square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the hallway outside the Pope's office, there are raised VOICES from behind the closed door.    Lt. Chartrand approaches nervously. He and the Guards look at each other, don't know what to do. From the other direction, Father Simeon, Cardinal Mortati's Aide, strides toward them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . SIMEON I demand to speak to the Camerlengo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: from behind the door draws their attention --what the hell is going on in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Langdon and Vittoria hit another gate, this one heavier, but it too is unlocked.    The sound of St. Peter's Square fades behind them now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: they turn a corner and, without warning --- the tunnel ends. There is only a thick iron door, and as Langdon searches it with his flashlight, he finds no handle, no knob, no keyhole, no hinges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a ROAR of anger, he starts to POUND on the door.      Vittoria joins in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Senza chiave!    A one-way portal, the only access is from the other side!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - HALLWAY        NIGHT CLOSE ON a watch -- 11:40.     Outside the door to the Pope's office, Lt. Chartrand is desperate. While Father Simeon attempts to argue with him in Italian, Chartrand turns, hearing the POUNDING coming from down the hall. He heads toward it, rounds a corner   -- INT      POPE'S PRIVATE LIBRARY       NIGHT -- and steps into the Pope's private library, where the POUNDING is louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps to a heavy door in the wall, looks unused for a century, but it's clearly the source of the sounds.    He looks down, sees three keyholes in the door, and an ancient key in each of them. Chartrand puts his ear to the door, hears VOICES    -- INT     IL PASSETTO      NIGHT -- and, on the other side, Langdon and Vittoria squint at the light as the heavy door is hauled open before them. Chartrand looks at them in amazement    -- how'd you get here?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Camerlengo is in danger!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Chartrand, Langdon, and Vittoria round the corner and race down the hallway toward the Pope's office, just as -- -- a BLOODCURDLING SCREAM comes from behind the closed doors. The Swiss Guard move fast, throwing open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Langdon and the others race into the pope's office and find a truly bizarre scene. Rocher is near the fireplace, brandishing his sidearm, aimed at the Camerlengo, who lays on the floor, writhing in agony. His cassock is torn open, and his bare chest is seared black.     A large, square brand is on the floor at Rocher's feet. Two of the Swiss Guard act without hesitation    -- they open fire. Two bullets SLAM into Rocher's chest and he crumples. Father Simeon bursts into the room, and as he does the Camerlengo rolls over onto one side, points his index finger at Simeon, and cries out a single word:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sanctimonious- He rushes at the Camerlengo and Chartrand reacts on instinct, putting three bullets in Father Simeon's back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He falls to the floor, dead. Chartrand and the Guards dash to the Camerlengo, who clutches his chest, convulsing in pain. Langdon walks toward him, stunned, as the Guards pull the Camerlengo's hands away from his wound, revealing the fifth brand. The crossed keys, seared into the flesh of his chest. Langdon looks at Rocher in utter disbelief. Rocher's still alive, trying to say something, holding out a hand. Everyone else in the room is focused on the Camerlengo, so Langdon bends down, takes the dying man's hand. Rocher looks up at him, desperation in his eyes, trying to communicate something but too weak to say more than:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And his eyes close. Langdon withdraws his hand from Rocher's, and finds the dying man has pressed something into his palm. A key. Langdon looks at it, and it gives him a thought. He turns, looks at the Camerlengo, whose chest is exposed. The crossed keys are indeed branded there      -- but they're upside down. Langdon slips the key in his pocket and approaches the Camerlengo as Chartrand gets to his feet, on his radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo struggles to a sitting position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Rocher, dead on the floor.        Back at the branded keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back at Rocher, and at Father Simeon, dead on the floor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . SIMEON You bastard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For safety.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need a Medevac to St. Peter's Square, right now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Order the evacuation.    We only have nineteen minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The keys.    They're upside down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think it's a sign?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything has been a sign, why should this be any different?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Crossed keys -- the symbol for the papacy, upside-down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: St. Peter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The first pope, he was crucified upside-down, on Vatican Hill.    Right beneath where we're standing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Upon this rock I will build my church."...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or bring it down upon itself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) They were conservatives, the former Pope was becoming more and more liberal.    Maybe they loved their church so much they were willing to destroy it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking, repeats) Upon this rock I will build my church.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: St. Peter's tomb is the very core of Christendom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The bomb is in St. Peter's tomb!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost admiring it) The ultimate infiltration.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can still change the battery if we hurry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE           NIGHT The square is more crowded than ever, and now the helicopter. Chartrand called SWOOPS in low overhead as Vatican Police frantically try to clear a landing area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S BASILICA          NIGHT Langdon, Vittoria, the Camerlengo, and two Swiss Guard are hurrying across the deserted floor of St. Peter's Basilica when the lights go out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They race down the center aisle, to the candlelit balustrade which surrounds the winding staircase into the grottoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grab one! They do, and run down the center stair. On the staircase, the ninety-nine burning oil lamps throw exaggerated shadows on stone walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. The Camerlengo drops to his knees and opens an iron grate in the marble floor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The grid is still cycling -- the power to this section must be down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oil lamps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's down here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Necropolis.    City of the dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vittoria, Langdon, the Camerlengo, and Chartrand drop down through an open hole and into an underground city of ancient, winding streets.    Part museum, part ruin, they run past ancient structures, some hundreds, some thousands of years old. The rectangular tombs are similar to little houses, complete with doorways, thresholds, windows, and terraces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Camerlengo seems to know exactly where he's going; he leads them down a narrow stone passageway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: they hurry up a small hill.    At the top of the grade, there is a stone grotto, toward which the Camerlengo is racing. He reaches the grotto, searches, but finds nothing. Langdon and Vittoria come to a stop behind him, breathing hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rips aside some protective tarps, finds that underneath the actual burial site is an underground area, part of a dig in progress. He climbs down into it, we see just the top of his head as   -- -- a soft glow seems to emanate from beneath him. The Camerlengo's head is wreathed in light for a moment, and then, as he climbs out, we see that he's holding in his hands -- -- the glowing canister of anti-matter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It must be here!    It must be!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vittoria drops to her knees, a tiny silver pellet in one hand, two wires leading from opposite ends of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo does.     Langdon bends close.   Vittoria checks the timer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans down, reaching for the canister's baseplate. As she does, a drop of sweat rolls to the tip of her nose She freezes. Wipes the sweat away, thinking about it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We may have less than five minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with that, he snatches up the canister and takes off running, back the way they came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he's already gone, around a darkened corner.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Set it down flat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) We still have seven minutes.   Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) It's hot down here.   Isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heat decreases battery life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I pull the power with less than five minutes, the residual charge won't hold suspension. We should leave it and get clear if we can. At least if it goes off down here the damage will be-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE           NIGHT In St. Peter's Square, the helicopter that was brought in for the Camerlengo waits, propellers spinning. The Crowd seems even bigger now, and a REPORTER tells us why:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: in St. Peter's Square where, despite a bomb threat and order of evacuation, the crowd is actually growing in size as we await -- 116.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S BASILICA           NIGHT The Camerlengo emerges from the spiral staircase, accidentally kicks over one of the oil lamps, spilling its burning oil on the floor of the Basilica. He ignores it, racing for the front doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Langdon and Vittoria come around a corner in the Necropolis, having taken slightly longer to find their way. Langdon spots the circular entry by which they first came in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They race toward it and climb up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There it is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S BASILICA           NIGHT They hurry across the floor of St. Peter's Basilica and burst out the huge doors that open onto St. Peter's Square, just as -- EXT      ST.   PETER'S SQUARE           NIGHT -- the helicopter lifts off. The Crowd watches in amazement, and the PILOT stands in the square, talking animatedly to two Swiss Guard, gesturing toward the helicopter.    But if he's not flying it... Langdon looks up at the helicopter as it climbs, straight upward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo is indeed at the controls of the helicopter, piloting it upwards and away from the crowd below.    The canister is beside him on the passenger seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE           NIGHT The crowd falls silent, all eyes turning upward, watching the helicopter recede into the clouds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The canister BEEPS on the seat beside the Camerlengo -- still a few minutes left on its timer, but the urgently flashing red power light can't be considered a good sign. The Camerlengo looks at it. Crosses himself. Raises the crucifix from around his neck and brushes it against his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE          NIGHT All eyes are upturned, all voices have fallen still, watching as the helicopter's anti-collision lights disappear into the clouded night sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: High above the square, the helicopter still climbs, rotating in circles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON the canister as the red light flashes even faster, and a shrill BEEPING fills the cockpit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE          NIGHT In the crowd, faces turn, PEOPLE point.        There's something in the sky above them. Langdon and Vittoria see it too -- a faint white speck, far up in the sky.    This is the explosion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, the faint white speck is a billowing parachute    -- and the Camerlengo dangles at the end of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the helicopter continues to climb, far up into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And in the canister, the BEEPING sound becomes continuous and the light winks out altogether.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The shimmering bead of anti-matter falls out of suspension and drops, slowly, toward the bottom of the canister, it barely touches the surface -- EXT     IN THE SKY         NIGHT -- and the helicopter explodes in a blinding pinpoint of white light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE          NIGHT Up in the sky over St. Peter's Square, the pinpoint of light is tiny at first, then it shoots out to either side in a searing white line, then the white line balloons out on either side, expanding into a gigantic ball of hot white light. And then the sound hits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is the explosion, and it is so much more ferocious than we could have imagined. The entire image is bleached white, with only the faint outlines of people visible within it. And then concussive force of the blast hits, like heat waves, rippling everything in its way.    SCREAMING and panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo, clinging to the parachute, is buffeted wildly, spun over and over, tangling him in his cords, which makes him fall faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE          NIGHT The second wave of the blast comes, and this one's ten times as powerful as the first. Everything standing is flattened -- PEOPLE, camera trucks, the fountain in the middle of the square collapses in a shower of marble and water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S BASILICA         NIGHT Ceiling tiles fall and SMASH on the floor inside St. Peter's, statues topple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo falls, unconscious now, tumbling over and over, dropping too fast. He SLAMS off an angled rooftop, headed for the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S SQUARE           NIGHT In the square, Langdon and Vittoria dodge falling debris. Vittoria loses her footing as a chunk of plaster CRUNCHES off a building, plummeting toward her. Langdon pulls her to safety as the plaster PULVERIZES itself in the square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo CRUNCHES off the side of another building and drifts downward, fast, toward the crowd in St. Peter's. His unconscious form SMASHES through a dozen people before SLAMMING to the ground at one edge of the square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the blast suddenly turns inward on itself, the heat and light and sound all seeming to suck back up into a perfect horizontal line, which then collapses in from the sides, until once again it is just a speck of white hot light -- -- that disappears into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    PETER'S SQUARE          NIGHT The only sound that remains in the square is a soft night wind. The wounded pick themselves up off the ground. The crowd, realizing the blast is over, turns its attention to the body of the Camerlengo, on the far side of the square. Langdon and Vittoria try to make their way toward him, but the crowd surges past them, and we soar over the heads of the crowd, wanting to get there first, wanting to be the first ones to see
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: his eyes open. He's alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a great CHEER rises up from the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CHEERS from outside are clearly audible in the Sistine Chapel, where the doors have been thrown open and they have gotten the news.    Jubilation reigns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: runs in, finds Cardinal Mortati.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo is alive!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he looks around him -- the Cardinals have split into small groups, they're discussing something with great animation amongst themselves. Mortati watches, doesn't like what he's seeing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Signore Mortati, he is alive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Praise God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Langdon and Vittoria, on a bench in the office of the Swiss Guard, are having superficial wounds treated.    The buzz in the office is intense, just as excited as in the square and the Sistine Chapel. Langdon looks over at Vittoria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks back at him, nods. Smiles. He reaches over, interlaces his fingers with hers, and takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles, turns his hand, noticing the glass on his wristwatch is broken.    He notices, seems distressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles and kisses the back of his hand
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: INT OFFICE OF THE SWISS GUARD NIGHT
result.heading: INT OFFICE OF THE SWISS GUARD NIGHT

dialogue.raw_text: Are you okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Thank God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do we have time for that story now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I have someone to tell it to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes from outside and we see -- EXT      ST.   PETER'S SQUARE           NIGHT -- the crowd in St. Peter's Square, in rapture. There is SINGING, there's CHANTING of the Camerlengo's name.    It's exactly midnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the Sistine Chapel, Cardinal Mortati is in hushed, urgent conversation with a group of seven or eight Cardinals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The African Cardinal who cast his vote earlier speaks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mortati looks at him.    Boxed into a corner. Outside, the crowd in St. Peter's can be heard, singing joyously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Signores... you are no doubt aware that by Holy Law the man is ineligible for election to the papacy.    He is not a cardinal, he is a priest, a chamberlain.    And there is the matter of his inadequate age.    I'm sorry, the protocols of conclave are not subject to modification.    I will not call a ballot on this matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Signore, you would not call the ballot.    Surely you remember -- you gave up your post as Great Elector.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: steps forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They are singing in St. Peter's Square!   What happened here tonight transcends our laws!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it?    Is it God's will that we abandon reason and give ourselves over to frenzy?   Discard the rules of the church?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: now, a peacemaker:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most of the Cardinals look puzzled -- but Mortati's face darkens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Second Cardinal sparks to this idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Many cries now of "Bring the Camerlengo to us!" Mortati looks deeply troubled.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps they need not be discarded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) I am thinking now of Romano Pontifici Eligendo, Numero 63.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Balloting is not the only method by which a Pope can be elected.    There is another, more divine method.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Acclimation by Adoration."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Si, signore!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course! (answering those around him who look confused) Election by Adoration occurs when all the cardinals, as if by inspiration of the Holy Spirit, freely and spontaneously, unanimously and aloud, proclaim one individual's name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the law states that Adoration supersedes all other eligibility requirements.    The candidate need only be an ordained member of the clergy. (DRAMATICALLY)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! (they listen) He must be present in the Sistine Chapel at the moment of election.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bandaged now, Langdon and Vittoria are ushered into Rocher's office by a Swiss Guardsman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shake their heads, no thanks.        Settle into chairs to the side of Rocher's desk. They look uncomfortable   -- it's weird to be in a dead man's office. Vittoria looks at his desk.     Thinks of something. She gets up and goes to it, running her hand lightly over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want them back. She feels in the surface of the desk and finds the square outline of the inlaid panel where Rocher hid the journals.    She tries prying it open, but that doesn't work, she tries pushing down on the front of it -- -- and the panel slowly rotates open.    The journals, which were laid on top of the television monitor, slide out and onto the desk. Vittoria scoops them up and is about to close the panel again when -- LANGDON Wait a minute. He looks down at the monitor.        Thinking. At its odd, key-shaped on/off switch. He pulls something from his pocket      -- the key Rocher gave him, just as he died.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please wait here while we arrange your transportation.    May I get you anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leonardo's journals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: he sees Rocher's face, looking up at him, dying:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For safety.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Langdon looks at the key, and its odd shape.    Looks down at the monitor, the same odd shape where its switch should be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: they're back in the Pope's office, but Rocher is alive, and saying words he said earlier:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Holy Father was subject to seizures... but he took steps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rocher's voice continues over, but Langdon mouths the words as he remembers them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocher is back in the office again, finishing his sentence:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For safety.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Langdon holds the key up, repeating those last words:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lowers the key to the monitor, extending it toward the keyhole
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For safety.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and it's a perfect fit.      He twists it. And with a ZZZZT of power, the monitor winks to life.   An image comes into focus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the monitor, they are indeed looking at an image of the Pope's office.    There are two dead bodies on the floor, covered with sheets, and VATICAN POLICE are photographing everything.    Must be live.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That...is the papal office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Langdon's figuring it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches down to the screen, toward a touch panel at the bottom. You don't have to be a symbologist to understand these symbols- play, pause, fast forward. And rewind.   Langdon touches it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Pope spent a lot of time in contemplation, alone.    If he was worried about seizures, he must have asked Rocher to install a camera without telling anyone.    To keep an eye on him.    For safety.    And maybe --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the image ZIPS backwards, rapidly, to the shooting, and the all the way back to when Rocher and the Camerlengo were alone together. Rocher stands just behind him, the Camerlengo still kneels before the fireplace. As the image starts to play forward, in real time, we go in close on the monitor and come out -- INT     POPE'S OFFICE       NIGHT -- in the papal office, to watch the scene in person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo turns his eyes back to the flames, stirring the embers with a poker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo twists the poker in the fire.     Speaks softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo looks up at him, and his expression is different than we've ever seen it.    Contemptuous.    Angry.    Violent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo looks at him calmly for a moment   -- 127.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The scientist kept journals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You figure prominently in them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leonardo wasn't just a physicist, he was a Catholic priest.    Deeply conflicted about the implications of his work and in need of spiritual guidance.    About a month ago, he requested an audience with the Pope. But you'd know that, because you granted the audience, and were present during it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fool thought he had duplicated the moment of creation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the Holy Father urged him to go public.    His Holiness thought the discovery might actually prove the existence of a divine power -- begin to bridge the gap between religion and science.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Science.    The new God.    Ignore the weapons and chaos and madness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) His work was not religious, it was sacrilegious!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you saw the Pope's position as a softening of church law.    An old man's weakness.    Your father's weakness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He raised me to protect the church. Even from within.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you brought an old enemy back from the dead to frighten people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing unites hearts like the presence of evil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It didn't work, Father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've informed Father Simeon of what I learned and he'll get word to the Cardinals the moment conclave opens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was planning on doing this alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and then removes the poker from the fire. But it isn't a poker, it's a long-handled brand, with a cross of some kind at the end. Rocher pulls his gun, holds it at his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo rips open his cassock with his free hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the Camerlengo RAMS the red-hot brand into the exposed flesh of his bare chest.    His skin SIZZLES and smokes, Rocher SHOUTS, the Camerlengo SCREAMS in agony, and we know the rest -- -- the door bursts open, Swiss Guard pour in, Rocher is shot, Father Simeon races toward the Camerlengo -- FR. SIMEON You bastard!       You sanctimonious-
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Put that down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But perhaps it's better that you're here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raising the gun) Put it down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and the Camerlengo rolls over, pointing one long finger at Father Simeon and CRYING OUT:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we saw before, Lt. Chartrand FIRES THREE TIMES, killing Father Simeon in his tracks, we pull back, the image turns to -- INT      ROCHER'S OFFICE      NIGHT -- video again, and as we complete the move out from the monitor, we see it isn't Langdon and Vittoria watching the image this time -- --- but Cardinal Mortati, flanked by two other red-robed Cardinals and a half-dozen Swiss Guardsman. Langdon and Vittoria stand to one side as Mortati turns and looks at them.    Suddenly, he seems very, very old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Camerlengo, escorted by two Swiss Guardsman, descends the Royal Staircase that leads to the Sistine Chapel. Though he is injured and limping, he radiates confidence, even benevolence, a man certain this is the greatest day of his life. He approaches the chapel doors, speaks to the Swiss Guard posted there as he approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, they know all about it.    They lift their swords, the doors sweep open, the Camerlengo strides boldly across the threshold -- INT     SISTINE CHAPEL       NIGHT -- and stops, right there, the look of imminent ascendancy frozen on his face. The Cardinals are looking at him, all right, but not in joy, not in wonder, not for leadership.    One hundred sixty-one faces are turned toward his, with an expression of --- -- utter condemnation. He stands there for a moment, searching their faces, trying to figure out what could possibly have happened. But it doesn't matter. They know.   And he knows they know. He takes two steps backwards, almost involuntarily. Starts to teeter, balances himself in the doorway. Then straightens himself, smoothes his cassock. And turns and walks away, back up the staircase. Two Swiss Guard move to go after him, quickly, but Cardinal Mortati gestures to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Swiss Guard follow the Camerlengo up the staircase.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have been summoned by the College of Cardinals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gently.    But within our walls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   PETER'S BASILICA      NIGHT The Camerlengo comes out of a doorway and into St. Peter's Basilica.    He heads for the main doors -- -- just as HALF A DOZEN SWISS GUARD step in from outside, blocking his way.    Some MURMUR softly into their radios. He stops, turns around to come back the way he came --- -- but TWO SWISS GUARD appear in that doorway, also with radios. He turns again, no way to go but toward the front of the Basilica. He sees the candlelit balustrade near the front, the one that leads to the grottoes and the Necropolis.    He picks up his pace. The Swiss Guard follow, at a slight distance. The Camerlengo reaches the spiral staircase and stops, looking down, seeing the oil lamp he kicked over earlier. He thinks.     He picks up a fresh lamp, holds it to his face    -- -- and blows out its flame with a soft PUFF.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: -- -- HE IGNITES IN A PILLAR OF WHITE FLAME

direction.raw_text: we're with the Swiss Guard as they walk slowly toward him. But they hear a CRY from ahead, he's gone down the stairs a short distance, and they can hear the sound of liquid SLOSHING. They break into a run as they realize what he's about to do, they're twenty feet away, then ten, then just close enough to see the Camerlengo as he -- -- SMASHES a burning oil lamp at his feet.     The flames leap onto his oil-soaked clothes and -- -- HE IGNITES IN A PILLAR OF WHITE FLAME.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON a bundle of one hundred sixty-one slips of paper, pierced by a needle and strung together. They're tossed into the fireplace in the Sistine Chapel, where they too burst into flame. We rise up again, ahead of the smoke this time, all the way up to      -- 130.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    PETER'S SQUARE          DAWN -- the chimney above St. Peter's Square, where the throng is still gathered, waiting for some word as the sun rises on the horizon. And this time, the smoke that billows from the chimney    -- -- is white. There is a new pope.    The crowd ROARS its approval, BELLS begin to toll -- INT     PAPAL APARTMENT          DAY -- the red silk sash covering the doors to the papal apartment is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: apart -- -- the wax seal BREAKS as the doors are flung open, and we   -- DISSOLVE TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    PETER'S SQUARE DAY -- St. Peter's Square, later the same day. The Crowd, if you can believe it, is even bigger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We move off the Reporter and up, toward the papal balcony, its doors hanging open, curtains billowing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Church sources now confirm that Camerlengo Father Sebastian Guttierez has died of internal injuries sustained in his heroic fall --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: which has spurred calls for his immediate canonization and sainthood. The Vatican also announced the death of three of its cardinals in the fire at Santa Maria Delia Vittoria --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: but all eyes here are on the papal balcony as we await the appearance of the new Holy Father, who, despite terrorist attempts at disruption --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: seems to have been selected in one of the swiftest and smoothest conclaves in modern church history.
dialogue.name: dialogue
